reason: The alpha annotation has been deprecated in favor of @targetName, which provides a more consistent and explicit mechanism for naming definitions externally.
Control where annotations are applied, as annotations on implicit classes only ended up on the class by default.
The API has been deprecated in Scala 3.7 as part of migration efforts, potentially to streamline the usage and structure of annotations.
Annotation classes need to be written in Java to ensure compatibility with Java classfiles.

Annotations extending 'Annotation' directly are not preserved in the classfile and are not stored in a Java-compatible manner. To make annotations available to Java reflection or tools requiring classfile preservation, 'StaticAnnotation' should be used instead.
To make a class a capability, let it derive from the Capability trait instead for better modularity and type safety.
Symbolic names in definitions, such as methods, now require the use of @targetName annotation for better clarity and consistency.
Used to mark definitions as experimental, likely to be refined or changed in future versions.
The `elidable` annotation is unsupported by the Scala 3 compiler and replaced with the `inline if` feature for compile-time behavior.
The `retainsCap` annotation is equivalent to `@retains[cap.type]` but consumes less bytecode.
Enhancements to language features have reduced the need for static annotations.

The 'tailrec' annotation ensures that a method or function is compiled with tail call optimization, and the ecosystem gradually transitions to improved constructs or methodologies in Scala versions past 3.8.

The `transparentTrait` annotation was introduced in Scala 2 to mark a trait as transparent, but in Scala 3, the `transparent` modifier was adopted for better consistency and functionality. Transparent traits are not inferred when combined with other types in an intersection.
Marked as experimental and replaced with a different optimization approach in Scala 3.8.
This annotation suppresses the creation of specialized forms based on enclosing specialized type parameters and has become obsolete in newer iterations of Scala.

In Scala 3, the visibility of methods added by the BeanProperty annotation changed, making them accessible only from Java (including Java reflection). This change ensures better encapsulation and alignment with Java Bean conventions.
The 'BooleanBeanProperty' annotation was updated to generate a Bean getter named 'isFieldName' instead of 'getFieldName', aligning better with JavaBeans conventions for boolean properties.
In Scala 3, methods added by the `@BeanProperty` annotation became visible only from Java (including via Java reflection), unlike in Scala 2 where they were visible from both Scala and Java.
The 'Exists' trait was deprecated to improve type handling and replaced by 'root.Result instances.' This change enhances expressiveness and compatibility with existential types.
Method's body now charges the deep capture set of the actual argument to the environment as part of its functionality.

Implicit conversions introduced by `ImplicitConversions` can cause unexpected issues such as type errors at compile-time. Explicit conversions provided by `scala.jdk.CollectionConverters` were recommended as a safer alternative to avoid such problems.

replaced_by: writeReplace method or custom serialization scheme
reason: Allows dynamic selection of factories for deserialization or enables developers to implement custom serialization schemes.
Optimization and reorganization of collection hierarchy for improved performance and clarity.
Introduction of new implicit definitions for enhanced compatibility with different iterable implementations and special cases, promoting flexibility and better performance.
The functionality of Subtractable is now implemented as part of SetOps and MapOps for consistency and improved design.
'conversion' is now renamed to 'apply' for consistency and improved method clarity.
'conversion' is now replaced by the method 'apply' as part of API modernization in Scala for better interaction with IterableOnce.
'conversion' has been replaced with 'apply' for greater flexibility and consistency in API design.
Simplification and consolidation of iterable-related traits to reduce redundancy and improve clarity.
AnyRefMap is deprecated. Likely due to a shift in preferred map implementations or performance considerations.
'conversion' is now a method named 'apply' to improve consistency and clarity in API design.
The functionality provided by the Subtractable trait has been integrated into other collection operation traits such as SetOps and MapOps.
Stream has a lazy tail only, whereas LazyList is fully lazy.
Direct access to implementation classes of BitSet is discouraged to promote encapsulation and future-proofing.
The operator `/:` is deprecated in favor of the more readable and standard `foldLeft`.

The use of `+` with varargs is no longer preferred. Users are encouraged to use `++` with an explicit collection argument for better readability and consistency.
Use ++ with an explicit collection argument instead of + with varargs to enhance clarity and performance.

The newer `iterableFactory` API provides similar functionality with improved consistency and usability.
The method '+'.was deprecated in favor of '++', which provides a more explicit and consistent way to add elements to a collection using a collection argument, rather than using varargs.
For sequential collections, aggregate degenerates to foldLeft. The combining operation for parallel collections is unused. Therefore, it is recommended to prefer foldLeft for sequential collections.
To optimize the serialization mechanism for LazyList instances and improve performance during serialization of long sequences.

The `toIterator` method was deprecated as it essentially duplicated the functionality of the `iterator` method, which provides the same result. Users are encouraged to use `iterator` instead for clarity and consistency.
The `Stream` has been deprecated in favor of `LazyList`, which provides a more consistent lazy computation model.
The 'List' API was deprecated to prioritize 'Vector' for better performance in terms of indexed access and large collection operations.

NumericRange provides a more generic and flexible implementation of numeric ranges, improving performance for arbitrary numeric types compared to `Range`.

Simplification and unification of API surface to avoid redundancy. The updated API offers a more concise and idiomatic way to perform the same functionality.

Stream has a lazy tail only, which could lead to unexpected lazy evaluation issues and stack overflow errors when working with long streams. LazyList is recommended as a fully lazy alternative that simplifies reasoning about lazy collections.

Use `scala.collection.mutable.HashMap` instead for better performance.

Specifies that using `dest ++= coll` instead of `copyToBuffer` is a better approach for collections of type Iterable.
Mutable `ListMap` has been replaced by the immutable version for better robustness and alignment with functional programming principles.

The `/:` method is deprecated in favor of `foldLeft` for better readability and consistency within the API.
Streamlining the API with dedicated range methods for better clarity and maintenance. Deprecated methods like `from`, `to`, and `until` are now grouped under the new range projection methods.
Type alias replaced to directly use `java.util.ConcurrentModificationException`
The `+` method was deprecated to encourage usage of `++` instead, which offers better consistency and clarity when explicitly specifying the collection to be appended.

The Successor feature for `Long` never worked, and after careful consideration it was decided to not support it at all.

Parser in ErrorKind is deprecated due to changes in runtime error testing functionality to allow more streamlined methods.
Refinement of ordering behavior for deadlines based on their finite duration properties.
The `span` token is used as a closing token for dot-less syntax. The introduction of `language.postfixOps` in later Scala versions now discourages dot-less style in favor of clearer syntax.

Usage of `prepare` caused complexity in capturing thread-local context for libraries consuming ExecutionContexts. It's recommended to capture thread-local context during the construction of the ExecutionContext instead.
Prepare method and its usage proved difficult to implement consistently. Instead, capturing thread-local context at construction is preferred over overriding or calling 'prepare'.

The `prepare` method proved difficult to implement in practice for capturing thread local context and was recommended to be avoided. Instead, thread local context should be captured during construction of an ExecutionContext.
Improved performance and synchronization features available in `java.util.concurrent.LinkedTransferQueue` as a modern replacement.
DelayedLazyVal will be removed in the future, possibly due to the availability of better alternatives or elimination of specific use cases.
Superseded by `scala.concurrent.Batchable` due to improved functionality and alignment with concurrent programming design.
Future.fold was deprecated in favor of Future.foldLeft for better API consistency and improved usage scenarios with non-blocking, asynchronous operations.
This method is semantically equivalent to `completeWith`. The naming convention was streamlined for clarity and consistency.
Enhance clarity by using factory methods directly from `ExecutionContext` for interoperability between Scala and Java concurrency classes.
The functionality provided by SyncChannel was replaced with java.util.concurrent.Exchanger, which is more robust and suitable for modern concurrency patterns.
The `SyncVar` is deprecated because `java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue` offers superior capabilities and is recommended for single-element container needs.
Transition to a more structured API to improve type safety and maintainability.
The `LowPriorityCodecImplicits` trait is marked as deprecated to simplify codec resolution and encourage explicit codec usage.
BufferedLineIterator uses an approach no longer suited to modern collection practices, and LazyList offers a more efficient and idiomatic alternative.

The `fromRawBytes` method assumed ISO-8859-1 encoding, which was considered inflexible. The `fromBytes` method allows users to specify any desired encoding, making it more versatile and aligned with modern encoding practices.

reason: LineIterator has been deprecated in favor of more consistent and flexible iterator alternatives.

The explicit conversion methods in this API are recommended only for Java code, while Scala code should use the extension methods in a different package, as extension methods are more idiomatic in Scala.

The explicit conversion methods defined in `scala.jdk.javaapi.FunctionConverters` are now intended for Java code usage. For Scala code, users are encouraged to use the extension methods defined in `scala.jdk.FunctionConverters`. This change enhances compatibility for Java code while recommending better alternatives for Scala developers.
Improved compatibility between Scala and Java, particularly when using scala.Option and java.util.Optional types in cross-platform integration scenarios. This includes addressing Scala's boxed types.
The `toIterator` method was deprecated in favor of directly using `.iterator` for clarity and consistency.

For sequential collections, `aggregate` degenerates to `foldLeft`. Therefore, it's advisable to use `foldLeft` for sequential collections where the combining operation provided by `aggregate` is not utilized.
Bridging write-handles like CompletableFuture and Promise was prone to race conditions. This change ensures conversion handles only read operations to prevent inconsistency.
To provide explicit Java-based implementation methods when writing Java code
The union method was replaced by concat for clarity and consistency in naming.

replaced_by: No direct replacement suggested, but addOne and addAll can be used instead of varargs +=
reason: Enhanced readability and consistency in method usage; varargs operations add ambiguity to the codebase.
To encourage the use of explicit conversion methods for Java Streams in Java code and improve interoperability between Scala and Java.
The `signum` method was deprecated in favor of the `sign` method for better functionality, as it allows direct usage of fractional types and aligns with modern standards

Implicit universal Equiv instance allows accidentally comparing instances of types with undefined equality or ill-implemented equality. Explicit Equiv.universal ensures better control and reduces potential errors.
The `isWhole` method on an integer type is always true and no longer serves practical use.

This implicit universal Equiv instance allows accidentally comparing instances of types for which equality isn't well-defined or implemented. The explicit usage of Equiv.universal avoids these potential issues.
The method was replaced by `sign` for consistency and clarity in naming of the operation.

The `Ordered` trait is intended for cases where data has a single, natural ordering (e.g., integers), while `Ordering` allows for multiple ordering implementations for the same type, providing greater flexibility.
Transition to a new approach using Ordering[T] for cleaner and more efficient functionality in Scala 3.7.

The default `Ordering` behavior changed to use `TotalOrdering`, aligning with `java.lang.Double.compare` semantics. Previously, `IeeeOrdering` was used based on IEEE 754 semantics, which caused inconsistencies in handling special cases like NaN comparisons.
The method `valueOrError` was deprecated in favor of `valueOrAbort`.
Enhanced integration with Scala 3 features, making ToExpr more efficient and extensible for users.
Improved type representation and subtype checking capabilities with `ClassTag`. The older API had type erasure limitations.

The `ClassManifest` API was intended for internal compiler use and was explicitly marked as such in Scala documentation. However, many libraries ignored the Scaladoc warnings and relied on `ClassManifest` in their code. The introduction of `ClassTag` aimed to provide a more robust and flexible alternative.

The functionality of `AnyValManifest` was largely subsumed by `TypeTag`, which offers more robust subtype checking capabilities and aligns better with the Scala compiler improvements. The previous API was deemed limiting and redundant.
ClassTag is limited to runtime type information about the top-level class of a type, whereas TypeTag captures full static type information including type arguments.
Enhanced support for type reflection introduced with TypeTag for more robust subtype checking.
OptManifest was deprecated due to redundancy and the introduction of the more versatile ClassTag API, which provides similar functionality.
Selectable was updated to support structural selections using Java reflection, and in Scala.js, a different implementation was required due to the unavailability of Java reflection.
The `sign` method provides a clearer API design by returning a value consistent with the concept of sign (i.e., -1, 0, 1) in type `T`, instead of an integer.
The `isWhole` method was deprecated because it has a fixed behavior for integer types, always returning `true`. This was deemed redundant and unnecessary for continuing functionality.
"isWhole" on an integer type is always true, therefore it was deprecated in favor of explicit checks using the "sign" method.
There is no need to round an integer type since the rounding operation is irrelevant for integers.
This is an integer type and there is no reason to use round, which is typically used for floating-point values. The method was deemed unnecessary and potentially misleading.

The `isWhole` method was deprecated because it always returns true for an integer type, making it redundant. The `signum` method was deprecated in favor of the `sign` method for clarity and usability.
The `signum` method does not handle -0.0f or Float.NaN correctly. The `sign` method offers improved accuracy and consistency.
Minimizing bytecode size and simplifying the codebase by encouraging use of Predef.nn instead of the inline extension.

The `isWhole` method does not provide any new information for integer types, as it is inherently always true for such types. The `signum` method is deprecated in favor of the `sign` method for clarity and consistency.
This API is deprecated since 'isWhole' is redundant for integer types, as it is always true for integers.
The `signum` method was superseded by the `sign` method for better consistency and functionality. The `sign` method provides a richer representation for determining the sign of a numeric value.

The `Tuple2Zipped` API has been deprecated since Scala 2.13.0 in favor of `LazyZip2`. This change aims to provide a clearer and more consistent naming convention in the standard library, as well as ensuring better functionality.
The API has been deprecated due to lack of use and better alternative approaches introduced in newer versions of Scala, focusing on improved functional programming paradigms.
The `signum` method does not handle -0.0 or Double.NaN properly, leading to potential inaccuracies. The `sign` method was introduced as a better alternative.
The API was deprecated to encourage the use of scala.collection.LazyZip2 for better functionality and flexibility.
The Tuple3Zipped API was deprecated in favor of scala.collection.LazyZip3 for better functionality and optimization.
Improved API design and functionality in `LazyZip3`, providing a more modular and efficient solution.
The functionality of `ZippedIterable2` has been replaced by `scala.collection.LazyZip2`, which provides a more efficient and modern approach for zipping iterables.
The `ZippedIterable3` API was deprecated in favor of `LazyZip3` from `scala.collection`, providing better functionality for zipping collections lazily.

The `NonLocalReturns` API has been deprecated because its functionality is better served by the `scala.util.boundary` and `scala.util.break` abstractions. The new abstractions work with plain `RuntimeExceptions` and are more performant, as returns within the scope of the same method can be rewritten by the compiler to jumps.

replaced_by: Direct methods on Either (because Either is now right-biased)
reason: The Either class is now right-biased, meaning that operations like map and flatMap directly apply to the Right instances of Either. The right projection is no longer needed.
Either is already right-biased, making the RightProjection class redundant. This change also simplifies the API and ensures consistency.
The Either API is now right-biased, making the right method redundant for most use cases.
FromDigits has undergone updates to simplify the conversion process and to enhance clarity while handling number literals with decimals or exponents.
ZippedIterable3 is deprecated and its usage is discouraged; scala.collection.LazyZip3 should be used instead for improved functionality and performance.

The `NotGiven` API was introduced in Dotty, the evolution of Scala, to address limitations in Scala 2 regarding implicit search and logical negation. In Scala 2, negation logic required ambiguous implicit setups and fallbacks, making it less transparent and harder to implement negation cleanly. Dotty introduced native support for negation with `NotGiven` in implicit searches, eliminating the need for indirect conditional ambiguity approaches.

The `between` method was deprecated due to potential misuse and unclear behavior when specifying ranges. The new method `nextInclusiveBetween` provides better clarity and enforces inclusivity at both bounds to mitigate errors.
ZippedIterable2 was deprecated in favor of scala.collection.LazyZip2 as it provides a more flexible and efficient API for lazy zipping.
The `Either` class was changed to be right-biased by default in Scala 2.13, making the `right` method redundant.
Unified names and improved performance for better handling of non-local returns and breaks.
LazyList was introduced as a better alternative to Stream due to performance improvements and a simplified API.

Starting with Scala 2.10, it became possible to extend `Any` directly using universal traits. This change was introduced to enhance inheritance of methods for value classes and simplify type hierarchies.

The `DelayedInit` feature was dropped in Scala 3, and `App` now exists in a limited form without support for command-line arguments. The change was introduced to provide a more concise and consistent scheme for creating programs that can be invoked from the command line in Scala 3.
Improving type constraint handling and compatibility between type equality and subtyping.
Redundant due to alternative methods for handling boxing and unboxing in Scala, improving type safety, clarity, and discouraging direct interaction with low-level runtime classes.
Shift towards a more robust and flexible typing system, including multiversal equality, while discouraging the use of universal equality.
Concatenating a number and a string using `+` is considered error-prone as it may lead to unexpected behaviors.
The `printf` function was marked for deprecation in favor of using `java.util.Formatter` for better formatting capabilities and enhanced compatibility with Java libraries.
DelayedInit semantics can be surprising. Support for `App` will continue as it is less error-prone and aligns better with core principles of the Scala language.
Adding a number and a String is deprecated due to potential misuse and unintended behavior.
Adding a number and a String using '+' was deprecated to encourage more consistent and robust string handling through string interpolation.
Adding a number and a String is deprecated to enforce stricter type safety and avoid unintended behavior.
The implementation is incorrect and calling it can crash the program.
Adding a number and a String is discouraged to improve code clarity and alignment with modern language design practices.
Implicit conversion from Long to Double is considered dangerous as it could lead to loss of precision, favoring explicit conversions for better clarity and to avoid ambiguity.
Implicit conversion from Int to Float is dangerous because it loses precision.
Adding a number and a String is deprecated due to ambiguity in operations and to encourage the use of explicit string interpolation.
Matchable was introduced to ensure safer type pattern matching and address issues with type compatibility, making Scala more type-safe.
To ensure compatibility with polymorphic method refinements and improve performance by erasing the type to FunctionN or FunctionXXL.
The 'Precise' trait transitioned to use precise mode for inference, restricting the widening of singleton and union types. This helps maintain better type precision within the Scala type system.
Simplification and unification of product traits for better code maintainability and readability.
The usage of Product7 API was likely shifted to its companion trait object.
Proxy and its methods are outdated, and explicit overrides of `hashCode`, `equals`, and `toString` are recommended.

Forwarding methods can create an asymmetric equals method, which is not recommended. Explicitly overriding `hashCode`, `equals`, and `toString` ensures better symmetry and consistency in object behavior.
Adding a number and a string directly is considered less intuitive and prone to errors.
Encourages static method usage for better efficiency and consistency.

The `scala.language.reflectiveCalls` feature used with `reflectiveSelectableFromLangReflectiveCalls` was deprecated because a newer and more specific method for reflective capabilities was provided (`reflectiveSelectable`). Subtypes now have more relaxed subtyping rules for refinements and precision in parameter dispatch was deemed unnecessary.
The treatEscapes method is deprecated in favor of processEscapes, which provides the same functionality.

Tuple16, as an immutable and canonical representation of `Product16`, is being phased out for better performance and flexibility in handling tuples of large arity. The `NonEmptyTuple` provides a more efficient structure for working with such cases.
The `Tuple19` class has been deprecated in modern versions of Scala to simplify tuple handling and encourage the use of more concise constructs such as `NonEmptyTuple`.
To streamline APIs and adopt a more modern tuple API structure in newer versions

replaced_by: t1 *: t2 *: t3 *: t4 *: t5 *: t6 *: t7 *: EmptyTuple
reason: To align with Scala's new tuple representation and better support for compiler optimization.
Plans to remove legacy error handling in favor of a more robust mechanism in future versions.

Inheritance from class with this annotation is deprecated as it is planned that the class will be finalized in a future version. This change is intended to alert developers to comply with the library's deprecation policies.

This method will be removed in the future. Library authors should state the library's deprecation policy in their documentation to give developers guidance on how long a deprecated definition will be preserved.

replaced_by: Use parameter name as a String instead of a Symbol
reason: The parameter name should be a String, not a Symbol. Using a String provides better clarity and aligns with newer coding practices.
The @native annotation was refined to require methods to be part of a class and not a trait for better compatibility and stricter type checking.
The `scala.language.higherKinds` import is no longer required explicitly.

Higher-kinded types no longer need explicit imports for usage. The import statement for higherKinds is redundant as the feature is now part of the general language implementation since version 2.13.1.

replaced_by: Removing the override and using the original method
reason: To encourage library authors to finalize methods and provide a clear deprecation policy for better long-term reliability of APIs.
The unsafeExceptions API was deprecated as part of Scala's migration to safer exception handling semantics under the `CanThrow` trait, aimed at improving code safety and reducing runtime errors.
